text: Yes, our tail hedge strategy works a little bit differently from many other tail hedge or crisis arbitrage strategies. It does not trade options at all. We do not, for example, buy put options. Because actually, tail hedging could be very easy if all you do is to buy out the money puts on the index. You definitely will hedge all the risk. The problem with that approach is that during the calm market, low fallacy market, or bullish market, you will lose a lot of option premium. Time decay of option is a serious problem for many tail hedge programs. So the main focus of a tail hedge program is not to hedge the tail, actually, because that's actually easy. The difficult part is to prevent it from losing so-called premium, insurance premium during calm times. And so what we trade is very simple. It's just a future, even as a defiant future. That's all we trade. And we apply an intraday breakout strategy, a trend-falling strategy to it. Now, you might ask, why would a trend-falling strategy be suitable as a tail hedge? Well, think about it. If, for example, you buy the S&P every time it goes up 1% and you exit, let's say, at the end of the day, what if that day the market goes up 10%? Clearly, we'll make 9%. And vice versa. If the market went down. We make 9%. We make 9%. So based on very simple arithmetic, you can see that an intraday trend-falling strategy on a day when the market has these huge moves will be able to generate sufficient return to cover whatever loss one might incur on the long-only portfolio, especially if the tail hedge strategy is levered appropriately. I do not suggest, of course, it's a one-to-one hedge ratio. You probably need to apply higher capital to a tail hedge strategy for those days than you have in a long-only portfolio. But with the appropriate hedge ratio, you will be able to have any loss, even overnight loss, that one might incur in a long-only portfolio.
